item.title: New ubuntu failed market ttly
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

Yeah to be honest, I’m not too happy with Karmic Koala. It’s probably the worse OS to come from Canonical ever. I wish they would stop their 6 month release cycle and only release a new OS when it is STABLE. I’m so tired of them hyping up a new OS, it comes out and it’s filled with bugs. This is the reason I left Microsoft several years ago.

In my experience of the 9.10 on my HP pavilion laptop:

  • I upgraded for one reason, they finally fixed full screen flash video
  • No sound - Kind of fixed, I have to reload the alsa drivers each time
  • Sleep mode crashes the computer - Fixed
  • Wireless inactivity crashes the computer - Fixed
  • Cannot change the login screen without killing the GDM - Not fixed
  • the new boot loader is kind of annoying that it doesn’t use menu.lst and you need to actually edit the bash code to remove entries or delete the old kernel files from /boot/. - Not fixed
  • GParted will not let me resize my ubuntu/vista partitions unless I reinstall the partition table which wipes out all my information. I might as well run fdisk and reinstall both operating systems.
  • Banshee included to get rid of rhythmbox. I am not a fan of banshee, they will stick around for a while unlike rhythmbox but their current version needs work and their LastFM plugin is an abomination compared to rhythmbox’s.
  • Since 9.04 (maybe even before) the bug report tool is in the menu list but refuses to start up. Used to work fine but now they say it’s strictly a command line tool and needs a few more passing arguments for it to launch. That’s retarded.

Also, I reinstalled Mac4Lin and rhythmbox stopped working. Worked fine on previous versions of ubuntu with Mac4Lin installed, but Karmic still has problems. If anyone wants to have a stable system for a while, stick with 9.04.

I’ve read a lot of those articles and honestly, I do not think they’re bullshit. It was kind of shameful that so many laptops like my own, experienced the same shit right when Canonical was competing with the new operating systems from Mac and Microsoft. On a college campus, everyone has a laptop and if the young are the ones experiencing the most problems, promoting Linux would continue to be a problem.

I may switch to fedora.

~Ron

Read full topic

item.title: New ubuntu failed market ttly
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You are right, it only worked on my desktop so far. I’ll upgrade my media center and laptops and my brothers computer later this week and report back.

edit:
Just completed my 3rd upgrade to 9.10, and every one worked great. Again, the article is bullshit.

Read full topic

item.title: New ubuntu failed market ttly
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:16, topic:312586”]I thought I might add, just upgraded my desktop running 64-bit Jaunty to this latest Karmic. Upgrade went without a hitch and I am happily using the latest ubuntu with KDE 3.5 thanks to these repos:
http://apt.pearsoncomputing.net/install.html (I was using it with intrepid and jaunty as well)

So, basically, this article is bullshit. :)[/quote]

It’s not bullshit, the installation just worked for you while there’s still a high percentage of people who have run into problems. Then again, the results from that poll are probably biased because people are more likely to visit the forums and go to that topic if they have a problem with their installation, not if everything worked fine.

Read full topic

item.title: New ubuntu failed market ttly
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Free software is supposed to improve with each new release. Take OS X, which gets faster. Cleaner. Better. Sure, they have a much smaller hardware base to work on, but it can be done. Ubuntu with the potential for thousands of developers surely can do a better job? Or at least, surely it could at least move forward??

Since when was OS X free software? And a ‘smaller hardware base’ is a bit of a stretch, try less than 10 extremely similar hardware platforms, all developed by the company developing the software. Would it support all of these different USB network adapters or graphics cards? No. It’s a horrible comparison.

In fact, the entire term “early adopter” refers to the fact that most experienced Ubuntu users upgrading to the latest version will always wait at least a month before doing so, in order to ensure most major bugs are fixed. Is this seriously acceptable? Is this what you expect from a Linux system? Surely this is some kind of morbid, ironic joke.

This is the whole purpose behind Linux and free software as a whole. The user always has a choice to stick with the old and stable, or the cutting-edge and potentially unstable. My servers are running Ubuntu 8.04 LTS and Debian Stable, I wouldn’t dream of installing the latest version of any Linux distro days after it was released, because I don’t like headaches, so I don’t ask for them.

edit:
Mopman’s point is perfectly valid too, so no need to go over that again.

edit2:

Canonical is not an open source company, they are just using free software to try and get a slice of the huge operating system market.

I don’t understand that one. As far as I know everything they have written is open source code and has been released under such a license. All of the NetworkManager, Jockey, even the web apps than run on their server like LaunchPad has all been released as open source code. Calling them ‘not an open source company’ is stupid or ignorant. Probably the former.

Read full topic

item.title: New ubuntu failed market ttly
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:2, topic:312586”]meh, contrived linkbait. hes trying very hard, but his points are trash

Sure, Jockey (the proprietary driver manager) warns that Ubuntu “cannot improve or fix these third party drivers,” but does the average user really know what that means? All they know is that their entire (supposedly stable) Linux box hard locks each time they log out or switch users.

For example, I would hope that the average computer user understands basic sentences. If not, I’m not sure we can blame Ubuntu for making linux look bad, I think it might be the entire userbase that can’t read :P[/quote]He has been using linux for longer than you therefore ur young and inexperienced therefore he is a cool old guy and therefore your arguments are void!

Read full topic

item.title: New ubuntu failed market ttly
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

meh, contrived linkbait. hes trying very hard, but his points are trash

Sure, Jockey (the proprietary driver manager) warns that Ubuntu “cannot improve or fix these third party drivers,” but does the average user really know what that means? All they know is that their entire (supposedly stable) Linux box hard locks each time they log out or switch users.

For example, I would hope that the average computer user understands basic sentences. If not, I’m not sure we can blame Ubuntu for making linux look bad, I think it might be the entire userbase that can’t read

Read full topic
